answers.answer: Hi Missile,I have a diagnosis of sensory motor polyneuropathy but we don't know yet what is causing it.  I just wanted to let you know that I have the muscle twitches body wide just like you described.  The ball of my left foot and 3 toes are numb as well.  Just wanted to let you know you are not alone with this.

Hi both - I too have had all over body twitches, together with ongoing leg and bone pains and foot pain/numbness.  I am now 38 years old.  I was once told that if you can't see the twitches - this is usually related to anxiety (yes, I know you both have probably heard of this word, alot!), but if you can actually see the twitches, this could be nerve/muscle related.  My twiches are quite noticeable, especially in my legs, left arm and both feet, but a nerve conductor I had done a year ago, ruled out nerve damage - so as Missile mentions, I too have just gotten used to them.  My leg/bone pain is what ails me the most at this time in my life.  I just take it a day at a time, as I am sure, if we are about to land up with any muscular illness, our bodies will give us fair warning.  Take care the both of you.

Thanks to both of you.  I have not heard that the twitches you cannot see are anxiety related so that helps a bit.  I was just concerned that the twitches that are constant in my foot are a bad sign because I had heard that twitches constant in one location are more related to MND.  But, I then happened upon the Peripheral Neuropahthy info that says that it is normal to get the twitches in the affected areas and my left foot is definately the most affected area.  Oh well, I guess each day without any more bad symptoms such as weakness, etc. is a good sign.  I'm hoping that by now (2 months later) I would have some other major symptoms!  Thanks again.Missile

Hi,How are you?Your symptoms certainly seem to be due to peripheral neuropathy due to B12 deficiency, also since they have improved after B12 injections.Have you been tested for diabetes?Diabetes can also cause peripheral neuropathy also and should be ruled out. At the moment the possibility of ALS or MND does not seem very likely.I would suggest you to continue with your medications and watch for few more days. If the symptoms still persist please consult a neurologist.

question: Hello.  I am a 39 (almost 40) year old female.  I have had all over muscle twitches on and off for years, and have really just gotten used to them.  However, about 2 months ago, along with having them all over my body, my left foot started to contantly twitch.  These twitches are a little different.  They are more quicker and more like "pops" sometimes, in addition to twitches.  I was really worried about ALS or something, although I have no weakness anywhere.  The only thing I can think of is that I found out around that time that I have a B12 deficiency (202).  I have since began injections.  I did notice that I was having some numbness in my toes in that foot, along with sharp pains in my feet.  From alot of research, I have I think come to the conclusion that I may have PN from the B12 def.  The pains are much better except I do notice them when I wake up and start to walk.  But the twitches in my left foot are still constant.  Is this anything anyone else has experienced?  I am really trying not to worry about a MND, but it is hard with all the twitching.  I guess from what I've read, by now I would have at least SOME weakness and I do not.  Please let me know what you think.Thanks!!Missile
title: muscle twitches wi/ peripheral neuropathy?
